Dieser Stein ist zwar immer noch sehr widerstandsfähig, hat aber eine gewisse Flexibilität und Leichtigkeit, die in der Natur nicht zu finden ist. Diese Eigenschaft ermöglicht die Herstellung bestimmter Gegenstände, die mit normalem Stein nicht machbar wären.

Der letzte Schritt bei der Erschaffung eines neuen Golems besteht darin, die Asche eines {@item Manual of Stone Golems|DMG|manual of golem creation} über den leblosen Körper zu streuen. Ein Teil dieser Asche bleibt an dem frisch erschaffenen Körper haften und kann zurückgewonnen werden. Natürlich kann mit einer so geringen Menge kein ganzer Körper belebt werden, aber sie kann dazu verwendet werden, eine viel kleinere Kreation zu beleben.

table.name: Gorgon
rows: Das natürlich gewonnene Öl der Gorgone ist ein sehr begehrtes Schmiermittel. Handwerker aus allen Bereichen können es für ihre Arbeit verwenden, und die Nachfrage übersteigt stets das Angebot.

entries: Gorgon Gas Sack
(Kann nur geerntet werden, wenn die Gorgone beim Tod die Fähigkeit "Versteinernder Atem" besitzt)

Die Gasdrüse einer Gorgone, die sich direkt hinter ihrer Nasenhöhle befindet. Sie ähnelt einem Luftballon, wenn sie aus Metallfolie hergestellt wäre. Wenn sie geerntet wird, kann man sie gut zusammendrücken, um die gleiche versteinernde Wirkung zu erzielen, die ihr Besitzer einst verwendete.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du den Sack zusammendrücken und ein versteinerndes Gas in einem Kegel von 30 Fuß freisetzen. Jede Kreatur in diesem Bereich muss einen Rettungswurf auf Konstitution {@dc 13} bestehen. Bei einem misslungenen Schutzwurf beginnt das Ziel, sich in Stein zu verwandeln und wird {@condition restrained}. Das {@condition restrained} Ziel muss den Rettungswurf am Ende seiner nächsten Runde wiederholen. Bei einem Erfolg endet der Effekt für das Ziel. Bei einem Fehlschlag ist das Ziel {@condition petrified}, bis es durch den {@spell greater restoration}-Zauber oder andere Magie befreit wird. Sobald der Sack aufgebraucht ist, wird er geleert und ist dann unbrauchbar.

rows: Die Hufe einer Gorgone ähneln mehr als alles andere einem Amboss. Es ist eine Ironie des Schicksals, dass sie oft von Schmieden auf ihren eigenen Ambossen nachgeschmiedet werden.

Es ist schwer zu entscheiden, ob es besser ist, durch die Hufe oder das Horn einer Gorgone zu sterben. In jedem Fall kann ein erfolgreich geerntetes Gorgonenhorn von einem geschickten Schmied zu einer furchterregenden Waffe veredelt werden.
{@filter +1 Lance, Trident, War Pick, Javelin or Spear|items|source=|type=|category=specific variant|base item=lance__phb;war pick__phb;trident__phb;javelin__phb;spear__phb|search=+1}

Die eisenähnliche Panzerung einer Gorgone ist unglaublich hart und dennoch geschmeidig und atmungsaktiv wie Haut. Sie ist daher ein einzigartiges und nützliches Material für die Herstellung feiner Rüstungen.
{@filter Any +1 Heavy Armor or Shield|items|source=|type=heavy armor;shield|category=specific variant|search=+1}

table.name: Grell
rows: Die gewaltigen Tentakel eines Grells eignen sich hervorragend als Peitschen, wenn sie entfernt, getrocknet, behandelt und mit einem Griff versehen werden. Viele Underdark-Gesellschaften haben Peitschen aus Grells gesehen, sowohl wegen ihrer Stärke als auch wegen ihres Einschüchterungsfaktors.

entries: Das Gift eines Grells ist dafür bekannt, dass es unglückliche Opfer lähmt und sie hilflos zurücklässt, während der Grell mit ihnen davonfliegt, um sie zu verschlingen. Durch Entfernen der Drüse, die sich dort befindet, wo die Tentakel auf den Körper treffen, kann dieses Gift extrahiert und gegen die eigenen Feinde eingesetzt werden.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Kann verwendet werden, um bis zu 5 Stück Hieb- oder Stich-Munition oder eine Hieb- oder Stich-Waffe zu ummanteln. Das Auftragen des Giftes dauert 1 Minute. In der nächsten Minute muss jede erfolgreich getroffene Kreatur einen {@dc 15} Rettungswurf auf die Konstitution bestehen oder {@condition poisoned} sein. Das {@condition poisoned} Ziel ist {@condition paralyzed}, und es kann den Rettungswurf am Ende jeder seiner Runden wiederholen, wobei der Effekt bei einem Erfolg endet.

rows: Die Haut eines Grells reagiert extrem empfindlich auf bestimmte Reize, die die Sinne der meisten Humanoiden völlig übergehen. Diese Haut, die nur sehr schwer intakt zu entfernen ist, kann zur Herstellung von Rüstungen verwendet werden, die ihrem Träger einen sechsten Sinn verleihen, der dem des Grells ähnelt.

table.name: Grick
rows: Die tödlichen Tentakel eines Gricks sind sowohl gummiartig als auch scharf. Nach längerem Zartmachen, Kochen und Würzen werden diese Tentakel jedoch zu einer Delikatesse, die mehrere Völker des Underdarks zu schätzen gelernt haben. Sie wird gewöhnlich mit einer Soße aus dem Blut des Gricks serviert. Es ist ein gewöhnungsbedürftiger Geschmack, um es vorsichtig auszudrücken.

Die Haut eines Gricks hat einen einzigartigen Farbton, der es ihm ermöglicht, sich mühelos in seine felsige Umgebung einzufügen. Die Haut lässt sich zwar nur schwer von ihrem gummiartigen Kadaver abziehen, aber sie eignet sich gut als Tarnkleidung.

table.name: Alpha Grick
rows: Die tödlichen Tentakel eines Gricks sind sowohl gummiartig als auch scharf. Nach längerem Zartmachen, Kochen und Würzen werden diese Tentakel jedoch zu einer Delikatesse, die mehrere Völker des Underdarks zu schätzen gelernt haben. Sie wird gewöhnlich mit einer Soße aus dem Blut des Gricks serviert. Es ist ein gewöhnungsbedürftiger Geschmack, um es vorsichtig auszudrücken.

Die Haut eines Gricks hat einen einzigartigen Farbton, der es ihm ermöglicht, sich mühelos in seine felsige Umgebung einzufügen. Die Haut lässt sich zwar nur schwer von ihrem gummiartigen Kadaver abziehen, aber sie eignet sich gut als Tarnkleidung.

Der Grick, der groß genug geworden ist, um andere Gricks als Alphatier anzuführen, ist normalerweise derjenige, der lange genug gelebt hat, um das meiste Zeug zu essen. Aufgrund des unersättlichen Appetits und der geringen Intelligenz des Gricks gehören zu diesen Dingen manchmal auch die Schätze der unglücklichen Opfer, die seinen Weg kreuzen. In seltenen Fällen können diese Schätze über einen längeren Zeitraum im Verdauungstrakt des Gricks verbleiben und eine Perle bilden. Diese Perle ähnelt dem Mischmasch, aus dem sie entstanden ist, ist aber mit einem übernatürlich dunklen Farbton überzogen, der trotz der Beleuchtung nicht verschwindet. Diese Perle kann von Kunsthandwerkern zu einem Gegenstand verarbeitet werden, der die ihr innewohnende Verbindung zum Underdark ausnutzt.

table.name: Griffon
rows: Die Krallen eines Greifen enthalten ein einzigartiges Kollagen, das bei der Verarbeitung einen hochwertigen Klebstoff ergibt. Dieser Klebstoff wird von Lederverarbeitern geschätzt und die meisten können nie genug davon finden, um ihren Bedarf zu decken.

Die makellosen Federn eines Gänsegeiers haben eine fast übernatürliche aerodynamische Qualität. Flieger und Scharfschützen schätzen gut erhaltene Gänsegeierfedern für die Herstellung hochwertiger Pfeile.

Ein Greif kann Beute erkennen, während er meilenweit über dem Boden fliegt, und potenzielle Rivalen aus großer Entfernung ausmachen. Ihre magischen Augen werden von den Bergvölkern seit langem als Zaubermittel und Medizin verwendet, aber die Nutzung ihrer Augen wurde von Kunsthandwerkern perfektioniert, die sie in eine Augenmaske des Adlers verwandeln können.

table.name: Grimlock
rows: Grimlocks sind eine erbärmliche Rasse, die von Menschen abstammt, die so feige waren, die Rasse der Illithiden als Gottheiten zu verehren. Dennoch kann ihre Erbärmlichkeit für den Rest von uns nützlich sein. Generationen, in denen sie den Experimenten und dem Einfluss der Illithiden ausgesetzt waren, haben zu einer dauerhaften physiologischen Veränderung im Gehirn der Grimlocks geführt, die, wenn sie zu einem Trank zusammengebraut werden, eine gewisse Immunität gegen die Fähigkeiten der Bewusstseinsveränderer verleihen kann.

table.name: Green Hag
rows: Das Haar einer grünen Hexe fließt wie verrottetes Schilf auf dem Grund eines Sumpfes. Es ist zwar unangenehm anzuschauen und in der Hand zu halten, besitzt aber einige schwache magische Eigenschaften und wird oft von schäbigeren Alchemisten verwendet, die nach einem billigen Ersatz für höherwertige Zutaten suchen.

Das Blut stinkt förmlich nach dem Gestank, der das gesamte Wesen der Hexe durchdrungen hat, und wenn man es trinkt, kann man eine Kreatur mit {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI} infizieren. Es sollte auch beachtet werden, dass das Blut zwar so stinkend riecht und schmeckt, wie es aussieht, dass aber Alkohol diese beiden Eigenschaften neutralisiert. Was jemand mit dieser Information anstellt, entzieht sich völlig der Kontrolle des Verfassers.

Grüne Hexen sind berüchtigt für ihre Fähigkeit, Geräusche zu imitieren, um Eindringlinge in ihre Höhlen zu locken oder zu erschrecken. Diese Fähigkeit verbleibt in ihrem Schädel und Kunsthandwerker können diese latente Kraft nutzen, um ein magisches Schmuckstück mit den gleichen Eigenschaften zu erschaffen. In mancherlei Hinsicht hätte die Hexe wahrscheinlich Gefallen an der Vorstellung gefunden, dass ihr Kadaver für solch eine makabre Tätigkeit verwendet wird.

entries: Nicht zu verwechseln mit dem berüchtigten "Hexenauge"-Amulett, das die Hexen ihren Dienern geben, aber die beiden sind eng miteinander verbunden. Obwohl es aus der Augenhöhle herausgetrennt wurde, scheint dieses Auge immer noch so zu strahlen wie zu Lebzeiten.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} auf den Hag-Augapfel einwirken, während er sich in deiner Hand befindet. Dabei kannst du das Auge der Hexe auf dieselbe Weise benutzen, wie sie es im Leben getan hätte. Wird das Auge der Hexe zerstört, während du {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrating} auf dem Auge der Hexe bist, erleidest du {@damage 3d10} psychischen Schaden und bist 24 Stunden lang {@condition blinded}.

table.name: Night Hag
rows: So dick und dunkel wie eine erstickende Nacht, trägt das Haar der Nachthexe einige der magischen Eigenschaften in sich, die einst von ihrem früheren Besitzer missbraucht wurden.

Das Blut stinkt förmlich nach dem Gestank, der das gesamte Wesen der Hexe durchdrungen hat, und wenn man es trinkt, kann man eine Kreatur mit {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI} infizieren. Es sollte auch beachtet werden, dass das Blut zwar so stinkend riecht und schmeckt, wie es aussieht, dass aber Alkohol diese beiden Eigenschaften neutralisiert. Was jemand mit dieser Information anstellt, entzieht sich völlig der Kontrolle des Verfassers.
Der Schädel der Nachthexe trägt noch immer dieselben dunklen Energien wie zu Lebzeiten in sich, die die Sterblichen verderben und sie mit Albträumen in den Wahnsinn treiben.

entries: Nicht zu verwechseln mit dem berüchtigten "Hexenauge"-Amulett, das die Hexen ihren Dienern geben, aber die beiden sind eng miteinander verbunden. Obwohl es aus der Augenhöhle herausgetrennt wurde, scheint dieses Auge immer noch so zu strahlen wie zu Lebzeiten.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} auf den Hag-Augapfel einwirken, während er sich in deiner Hand befindet. Dabei kannst du das Auge der Hexe auf dieselbe Weise benutzen, wie sie es im Leben getan hätte. Wird das Auge der Hexe zerstört, während du {@item concentration|PHB|concentrating} auf dem Auge der Hexe bist, erleidest du {@damage 3d10} psychischen Schaden und bist 24 Stunden lang {@condition blinded}.

table.name: Sea Hag
rows: Das Haar einer Seehexe, das verrottetem Seetang ähnelt, kann gewaschen, in Scheiben geschnitten, getrocknet und dann über einen längeren Zeitraum eingeweicht werden, um einen Trank der Wasseratmung herzustellen. Es sollte jedoch gewarnt werden, dass das Trinken eines aus Seehexenhaaren hergestellten Trankes das Potenzial hat, ein Opfer mit {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI} zu infizieren.

Das Blut stinkt förmlich nach dem Gestank, der das gesamte Wesen der Hexe durchdrungen hat, und wenn man es trinkt, kann man eine Kreatur mit {@disease crone's disease|HHHVI} infizieren. Es sollte auch beachtet werden, dass das Blut zwar so stinkend riecht und schmeckt, wie es aussieht, dass aber Alkohol diese beiden Eigenschaften neutralisiert. Was jemand mit dieser Information anstellt, entzieht sich völlig der Kontrolle des Verfassers.
Der Schädel der Meerhexe hat zwar keine charakteristischen Gesichtszüge mehr, aber er strahlt immer noch eine bösartige Aura aus, die jeden erschaudern lässt, der ihn ansieht.

entries: Nicht zu verwechseln mit dem berüchtigten "Hexenauge"-Amulett, das die Hexen ihren Dienern geben, aber die beiden sind eng miteinander verbunden. Obwohl es aus der Augenhöhle herausgetrennt wurde, scheint dieses Auge immer noch so zu strahlen wie zu Lebzeiten.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} auf den Hag-Augapfel einwirken, während er sich in deiner Hand befindet. Dabei kannst du das Auge der Hexe auf dieselbe Weise benutzen, wie sie es im Leben getan hätte. Wird das Auge der Hexe zerstört, während du {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrating} auf dem Auge der Hexe bist, erleidest du {@damage 3d10} psychischen Schaden und bist 24 Stunden lang {@condition blinded}.

table.name: Half Dragon

entries: Während normales Drachenblut zu fremdartig ist, um auf einen Humanoiden ohne erhebliche Veränderungen zu wirken, kann das verdünnte Blut eines Halbdrachens einem Humanoiden, der es trinkt, erhebliche Vorteile verschaffen.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du die Phiole mit Halbdrachenblut trinken. Für die nächsten 10 Minuten erhältst du die gleiche Art von Schadensresistenz wie der Halbdrache, dem es entnommen wurde.

rows: Halbdrachen nehmen in der Taxonomie der Kreaturen eine seltsame Stellung ein. Dies spiegelt sich am besten in der seltsamen Wirkung wider, die ihre Körper auf die Sinne der echten Drachen in ihrer Umgebung haben. Ihre seltsame Physiologie scheint dazu zu führen, dass sie von Drachen ihrer eigenen Farbe nicht bemerkt werden und diese sie für einen ihrer eigenen Drachen halten. Wenn man die Schuppen eines Halbdrachen nimmt, sie zu einem Pulver mahlt und dann mit Öl vermischt, entsteht eine Paste, die andere Humanoide auf ihren eigenen Körper auftragen können, um die Entdeckung durch Drachen zu vermeiden oder zu fördern.

table.name: Harpy
rows: Harpyienfedern sind auffallend groß, aber von feiner Qualität und spiegeln die schöne, aber gefährliche Natur der Harpyien wider. Sie sind zu groß zum Befiedern, eignen sich aber hervorragend für Federkiele.

Wenn Harpyien für eine Sache bekannt sind, dann ist es ihr Gesang. Ihre Stimmbänder sind in der Lage, eine Vielzahl von Klängen zu erzeugen, und einige wagemutige Barden haben sie als Saiten für ihre Instrumente benutzt. Von Barden mit Harpyieninstrumenten wird gesagt, dass sie Musik spielen können, die ganze Räume mit Zuhörern füllen kann.

In seltenen Fällen kann es vorkommen, dass Sie eine Harpyie erlegen, die sich mitten im Eisprung befindet. Ob das Ei befruchtet ist, spielt dabei keine Rolle, denn der wahre Wert liegt in der Schale des Eies. Wenn diese rosa gesprenkelte Schale pulverisiert wird, ergibt sie einen Farbstoff mit starken magischen Fähigkeiten.

entries: Wenn ein Höllenhund stirbt, wird er von seinem inneren Feuer verzehrt und hinterlässt nichts als Asche aus verbranntem Fell. Das ist zwar enttäuschend für die Sammler, aber das Fell hat noch einen gewissen Nutzen.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du dir 1 Büschel Höllenhundfell in die Hände reiben. Wenn du dies tust, darfst du in der nächsten Minute jedes Mal, wenn du bei einem Würfelwurf für Feuerschaden eine 1 oder 2 würfelst, den Würfel neu werfen und musst die neue Zahl verwenden. Nach seiner Verwendung verliert das Höllenhundfell seine Magie und wird unbrauchbar.

table.name: Helmed Horror
rows: Für die Herstellung eines behelmten Grauens ist kein gewöhnlicher Helm geeignet. Es muss ein speziell angefertigter Helm in Auftrag gegeben werden, um die einzigartigen Sinne des behelmten Grauens zu erhalten. Mit etwas Zeit kann ein Kunsthandwerker einen dieser Helme nehmen und die arkanen Signaturen so umgestalten, dass sie für normale Humanoide funktionieren.

entries: Der belebende Geist eines behelmten Grauens löst sich schnell auf, nachdem seine Form ihre strukturelle Integrität verloren hat. Wenn man sich beeilt, kann man diesen Geist mit einem Bogen von {@item spirit paper|HHHVI} einfangen. Egal, wie schnell du bist, ein Teil des Geistes wird sich bereits aufgelöst haben, so dass jeder Versuch, den Geist wiederzuverwenden, mit Sicherheit zu einem minderwertigeren Konstrukt führt als der ursprüngliche behelmte Schrecken. {@b Requires {@item spirit paper|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: Du kannst eine Stunde lang eine {@dc 15} Intelligenzüberprüfung ({@skill Arcana}) mit dem {@item spirit paper|HHHVI} durchführen, um die Essenz auf eine ungetragene {@item plate armor|PHB} Rüstung zu übertragen. Wenn du erfolgreich bist, verlässt die Essenz die {@item spirit paper|HHHVI} und tritt in die Rüstung ein, wodurch eine {@creature animated armor} unter deiner Kontrolle entsteht. Diese Rüstung befolgt deine Anweisungen nach bestem Wissen und Gewissen, verfügt aber nicht über die Intelligenz, um Nuancen in deinen Worten zu erkennen, und führt die Befehle buchstabengetreu aus. Diese {@creature animated armor} bleibt bestehen, bis sie zerstört wird.

table.name: Hippogriff
rows: Die Hufe eines Hippogreifs enthalten ein einzigartiges Kollagen, das beim Verputzen einen hochwertigen Klebstoff ergibt. Dieser Klebstoff wird von Lederverarbeitern sehr geschätzt, und die meisten können nie genug davon finden, um ihre Nachfrage zu decken.

Die unberührten Federn eines Hippogreifs haben eine fast übernatürliche aerodynamische Qualität. Fliegenfischer und Scharfschützen schätzen gut erhaltene Hippogreif-Federn für die Befiederung hochwertiger Pfeile.

Es heißt, dass ein Hippogreif eine Maus auf einem Feld aus einer Entfernung von mehr als 2 Meilen erkennen kann. Ob das nun stimmt oder nicht, sie können auf jeden Fall einen orkischen Hinterhalt aus ein paar hundert Metern Entfernung erkennen, und das ist ein weiterer Grund, warum Hippogreife als Reittiere und Begleiter so hoch geschätzt werden.

table.name: Hobgoblin
rows: Der Körper eines Hobgoblins hat für Erntehelfer wenig praktischen Nutzen. Die meisten Städte zahlen jedoch kleine Kopfgelder für Hobgoblin-Ohren.

table.name: Hobgoblin Captain
rows: Der Körper eines Hobgoblins hat für Erntehelfer wenig praktischen Nutzen. Die meisten Städte zahlen jedoch kleine Kopfgelder für Hobgoblin-Ohren.

Wenn ein Hobgoblin an Erfahrung und Prestige gewinnt, wachsen ihm die Haare zu Zöpfen, die nur abgeschnitten werden, wenn er einen Kampf verliert. Diese Zöpfe sind sowohl für Sammler als auch für Kopfgeldjäger von gewissem Wert, da sie beweisen, dass ein Hobgoblin eine nennenswerte Bedrohung darstellt.

table.name: Hobgoblin Warlord
rows: Der Körper eines Hobgoblins hat für Erntehelfer wenig praktischen Nutzen. Die meisten Städte zahlen jedoch kleine Kopfgelder für Hobgoblin-Ohren.

Wenn ein Hobgoblin an Erfahrung und Prestige gewinnt, wachsen ihm die Haare zu Zöpfen, die nur abgeschnitten werden, wenn er einen Kampf verliert. Diese Zöpfe sind sowohl für Sammler als auch für Kopfgeldjäger von gewissem Wert, da sie beweisen, dass ein Hobgoblin eine nennenswerte Bedrohung darstellt.

Wenn ein Hobgoblin so mächtig wird, dass er als Kriegsherr gilt, erhält er ein besonderes Zeichen, um sich im Angesicht seiner Gottheit zu verehren: {@deity Maglubiyet|Nonhuman|PHB}. Wenn dieses Zeichen richtig gehäutet und aufbewahrt wird, können Thaumaturgen daraus ein Schmuckstück herstellen, das den furchterregenden Einfluss des Goblin-Gottes ausstrahlt.

table.name: Hobgoblin Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} Tage im Wert von {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}

table.name: Homunculus
rows: Der zerstörte Körper eines Homunkulus zerfällt nach seinem Tod in seine weltlichen Bestandteile. Diese Bestandteile können zu einem neuen Homunkulus recycelt werden.

entries: Das Blut des Homunkulus ist das gleiche wie das seines Meisters: Ein Zauberer muss auf ein leeres Konstrukt bluten, um es zum Leben zu erwecken. Dies verleiht dem Zauberer eine für ihn nützliche Verbindung, kann aber auch von anderen, die in den arkanen Künsten bewandert sind, ausgenutzt werden, wenn es ihnen gelingt, den Homunkulus zu fangen. Daher kann der Preis für dieses Blut stark variieren, je nachdem, von welchem Homunkulus des Zauberers es stammt. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: Als Aktion kannst du das Blut des Homunkulus trinken. Dadurch erhältst du das gesamte Wissen, das der Homunkulus bis zu seinem Tod hatte, einschließlich der Sprachen, die er kannte, und des Wissens, das sein Schöpfer mit ihm teilte. Es kann sein, dass du nicht alles von diesem Wissen verstehst, vor allem, wenn es sehr esoterischer Natur ist, und dass du nicht in der Lage bist, es zu analysieren. Du behältst dieses Wissen für 10 Minuten, danach verschwindet es aus deinem Geist. Sobald dies geschieht, wirst du für 1 Minute zu {@condition stunned}, während sich dein Verstand von der Informationsflut erholt, die er erhalten hat.

table.name: Hooked Horror
rows: Das Exoskelett des Hakenhorrors ist härter als Eisen, lässt sich aber leider nur schwer umformen und eignet sich daher nicht als Rüstung. Es hat jedoch mehrere andere Verwendungsmöglichkeiten, wie z. B. als robustes Behältnis, Baumaterial oder sogar als Schlaginstrument mit Hall. Viele Underdark-Kulturen schätzen daher diese Exoskelette, wenn sie in gutem Zustand geborgen werden.

Die extrem empfindliche Gehörschnecke des Hakenhorrors ist der einer Fledermaus nicht unähnlich. Sie ist in der Lage, sowohl extreme Entfernungen als auch verschiedene Wellenlängen zu hören und dient als Schlüsselkomponente für verschiedene Hörgeräte und magische Gegenstände.

Die namensgebenden Haken des Hooked Horror. Geformt aus einem extrem harten, aber nachgiebigen Keratinmaterial. Mit geringfügigen Modifikationen können diese Haken in einen gewaltigen Kriegshaken verwandelt werden, der auch als Kletterhaken verwendet werden kann.

table.name: Hydra
rows: Die Schuppen einer Hydra haben eine lange Geschichte als Kunstmaterial in Küstengesellschaften; Hydren sind dafür bekannt, dass sie im Laufe ihres Lebens viele Schuppen abwerfen. Sie sind haltbar und haben einen einzigartigen Farbton, was ihnen eine einschüchternde Ästhetik verleiht, die viele Schneider gerne in die Hände bekommen würden.

Hydren sind für ihre regenerativen Fähigkeiten bekannt, eine Eigenschaft, die den Alchemisten nicht verborgen geblieben ist. Tatsächlich ist Hydrablut einer von vielen potenziellen Katalysatoren für die Herstellung des allgegenwärtigen Heiltranks. Das kräftige Blut der Hydra ist dafür bekannt, dass man daraus besonders wirksame Mischungen brauen kann.

Unglaublich scharf und unglaublich zahlreich. Küstengesellschaften sind dafür bekannt, dass sie tödliche Pfeile und Speerspitzen aus den vielen Zähnen herstellen, die Hydras hinterlassen, wenn sie ihre Köpfe verlieren und neue wachsen.

entries: An organ capable of scaling up blood circulation regardless of how many heads its body grows, the heart of a hydra is brimming with magical potential. In fact, the heart of a hydra is so powerful that consuming one can even regrow lost limbs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: It takes 10 minutes to consume enough hydra heart to have an effect. Once consumed, you regain all hit points as well as regrow any missing body parts. If a body part is regrown in this way, you feel an intense feeling of hunger and suffer 1 level of {@condition exhaustion} until you consume at least 5 pounds of food. The hydra heart must be consumed within 24 hours upon the death of the hydra, otherwise it gives no effect.

rows: A hydra's spine is a unique piece of biology, capable of adapting itself to more heads than it was originally suited for. Certain vertebrae in particular are noted for holding strong magic, and when used together can make a powerful healing staff.

entries: The fluid that oozes through an intellect devourer is not unlike the mucus secreted by their illithid masters. This fluid however has the unique ability to carry and pass on memories to those that consume it.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may drink a vial of brain fluid. If you do so you must make a {@dc 12} Intelligence saving throw. On a failure, you become {@condition stunned} for 1 minute as your mind fails to process the information flooding through it. On a success, you learn the identity of who this intellect devourer used to be, as well as one key memory. The key memory is up to the discretion of the DM, but may be something that the intellect devourer knew in its original life, or something it has learned after becoming an intellect devourer.

Living is a strong word in this case. Used here, it really means that the brain still has some capacity for interaction and response to stimuli, due largely to the dark rituals used to transform it into an intellect devourer. While it would be much more merciful to put the brain out of its misery by destroying it entirely, it still offers some use for an adventurer with a strong stomach.

entries.name: Use:
entries: For 6 hours after an intellect devourer's death, its main brain continues to send weak signals of psionic wavelengths. When the brain is worn directly on top of a humanoid's head, that humanoid becomes immune to the detect sentience ability of intellect devourers. Instead, an intellect devourer that detects that humanoid will assume that humanoid is a host of a living intellect devourer and will treat them accordingly. However, an intellect devourer that can see without using its {@sense blindsight} will still notice that a humanoid is wearing a brain on the top of their head and will also react accordingly.

table.name: Invisible Stalker
rows: Wenn sich die beschworene Form eines Luftelementars auflöst, hinterlässt sie kleine Staubklumpen, die weiterhin Spuren von elementarer Energie enthalten. Diese müssen schnell in speziellen Behältern gesammelt werden, um einen weiteren Verfall zu verhindern. Wenn sie richtig gesammelt werden, können sie zur Herstellung eines Elementar-Edelsteins verwendet werden. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

When an invisible stalker is defeated before it can fulfill its mission, a single wisp of a breeze remains that futilely attempts to make its way to its quarry. If this wisp is captured quickly and prevented from further degradation, it will continue indefinitely attempting to reach its quarry. Resourceful trackers mix small amounts of dye into this container to make a makeshift compass that will lead them to whatever the invisible stalker was originally trying to hunt. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries: The mesmerising eyes of a jackalwere are able to lure unwary travellers into a slumber, and many commonfolk that live in areas frequented by jackalweres make a habit of looking down when speaking to strangers.

entries.name: Use:
entries: If you cast the {@spell sleep} spell you may use a jackalwere eye as a material component. If you do so, you roll an additional {@dice 1d8} when determining the amount of hit points affected. You may only use one jackalwere eye at a time, and once used, a jackalwere eye loses its magic and becomes useless.

table.name: Kenku
rows: Seeing as how kenku are unable to fly, their feathers are largely vestigial. Still, despite their often dirty nature, they make for good quills. In fact, a good way to spot a kenku forger is to look for one that has bald patches over their body.

Other than their propensity for thievery, kenku are known for their uncanny mimicry abilities. Indeed, a kenku's voice-box is one of the most complex and well developed among any humanoid, and particularly resourceful tinkers have figured out how to modify them into unique musical trinkets and instruments. It would be advised however to avoid anyone willing to indulge in such a macabre craft.

table.name: Kenku Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} Tage im Wert von {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}
{@item Ball Bearings (bag of 1,000)|PHB|1 bag of ball bearings}

table.name: Winged Kobold
rows: Like a crocodile, kobolds continuously grow and lose teeth throughout their lives. As such, their jaws tend to be lined with razor sharp rows of fresh pearly-whites. Kobolds use these for tools and there is no reason why other races should refuse to do the same if the opportunity presented itself.

On a rare occasion, a kobold is born with a pair of wings. While small and relatively weak, the canvas-like skin make for a comfortable connective material in leatherworking. Of course, most leatherworkers advertise it "dragon flaps," since that has a nicer sound than "dead kobold skin."

table.name: Kobold
rows: Like a crocodile, kobolds continuously grow and lose teeth throughout their lives. As such, their jaws tend to be lined with razor sharp rows of fresh pearly-whites. Kobolds use these for tools and there is no reason why other races should refuse to do the same if the opportunity presented itself.

table.name: Kobold Trinket Table
rows: 25 feet of frayed {@item Hempen Rope (50 feet)|PHB|rope}

table.name: Kraken
rows: If anything betrays the kraken's blasphemous nature, it is the vile ichor that it tries to pass off as blood. Reeking of rotten fish and feeling just as slimy, the kraken's blood nonetheless is coveted by alchemists for its intense alchemical potential.

The ink of the kraken is vastly different to that secreted by a mere octopus. With a darkness that seems to leech the light around it, and a chemical mixture venomous to most creatures, this ink naturally has been weaponised by intrepid alchemists.

A kraken's tooth is hard and sharp enough to cleave right through the hull of a ship. With that in mind, they make fantastic heads for ballistae bolts and harpoons, and navies reserve their "kraken bolts" for only the flagship of their enemies.

A kraken's hide is at once tough and rubbery, capable of absorbing even magically imbued strikes with ease. Only the greatest of tanners are able to work with this hide, and only certain choice sections of it, but those who can are capable of crafting an extremely powerful set of clothes for the marining adventurer.

As both armies and gods can attest, the scales of a kraken are nigh impenetrable, even with magically powered strikes. Particularly prized is the scale located on the crown of the kraken's head which is both incredibly hard and the easiest to work with. Removing them is incredibly difficult however, and takes no small amount of elbow grease. Once pried off, they may be re-crafted into a special shield by a blacksmith that has reached the zenith of their craft.

The kraken has most likely forgotten more than ordinary mortals will ever hope to learn. From its watery domains, it has scoured ocean caverns hiding mysteries and treasures that surface dwellers were never meant to see. By taking a kraken's eye and subjecting it to a number of arcane rituals, these secrets can be revealed to a mind capable of handling them.

entries: Not many are aware that a kraken possesses 3 hearts, each with a slightly different circulatory function. In artificing function however they all serve the same purpose. By transfiguring them into crystals, they can be placed around a certain perimeter to act as wards against disastrous environmental effects. Many of the oldest port cities owe their longevity to these wards, or they would have been swept away by the tides long ago.

entries.name: Use:
entries: An artificer may spend 1 year performing a daily ritual to transform a kraken heart into a large red crystal with the ability to dampen natural forces. When 3 of these crystals are placed within 5 miles of each other, the area enclosed by them always experiences fair weather. Rain in that area never results in flooding, and waves are magically prevented from washing past the perimeter of that area.

rows: Like some cephalopods, the brain of a kraken is actually divided into several areas, particularly focused in their tentacles. In order to facilitate this odd physiology on such a large scale, the main brain of the kraken has a certain electromagnetic quality to it that not only allows it to control its massive body, but also influence sea creatures and the area around it. If the right areas are harvested, they make a powerful amulet that can mimic some of these abilities.

table.name: Kuo-Toa
rows: The bite of a kuo-toa is not particularly deadly to anything larger than a river fish. Their unique shape however lends them well to doubling as fishing hooks, and many anglers swear that their yields increase when using kuo-toa hooks.
Kuo-toa skin is notoriously slippery, owing to a mucus that the kuo-toa produces at all times. Soaking a fresh skin in this mucus helps to create a waterproof, if disgusting, tarp.

The brain of the kuo-toa is one racked by madness as a result of generations of exposure to illithid domination. Placing this brain in a crucible, removing impurities, and then boiling with various compatible catalysts creates a potion that can grant a drinker some of the otherworldly senses of a kuo-toa.

table.name: Kuo-Toa Archpriest
rows: The bite of a kuo-toa is not particularly deadly to anything larger than a river fish. Their unique shape however lends them well to doubling as fishing hooks, and many anglers swear that their yields increase when using kuo-toa hooks.
Kuo-toa skin is notoriously slippery, owing to a mucus that the kuo-toa produces at all times. Soaking a fresh skin in this mucus helps to create a waterproof, if disgusting, tarp.

A kuo-toa archpriest's brain has become noticeably more mutated that allows it to both use and bestow spells upon others. This unique brain is both more fragile than a regular kuo-toa's but also more useful in alchemy.

table.name: Kuo-Toa Whip
rows: The bite of a kuo-toa is not particularly deadly to anything larger than a river fish. Their unique shape however lends them well to doubling as fishing hooks, and many anglers swear that their yields increase when using kuo-toa hooks.
Kuo-toa skin is notoriously slippery, owing to a mucus that the kuo-toa produces at all times. Soaking a fresh skin in this mucus helps to create a waterproof, if disgusting, tarp.

The brain of the kuo-toa is one racked by madness as a result of generations of exposure to illithid domination. Placing this brain in a crucible, removing impurities, and then boiling with various compatible catalysts creates a potion that can grant a drinker some of the otherworldly senses of a kuo-toa.

table.name: Kuo-Toa Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} days' worth of {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations} (dried fish and seaweed)

table.name: Lamia
rows: As servants of Graz'zt, lamias are the living embodiment of charm and lust. Their blood reflects this and is one of many potential catalysts used when brewing the dreaded philter of love.

Those that have felt the gentle caress of a lamia know that there is a powerful magic imbued in their limbs. With some careful crafting, this magic can be harnessed into a weapon even beyond the death of its original owner.

Lamias treasure beauty above all else, going so far as casting illusions on their own realms to increase their aesthetic appeal. These visions of beauty are so persistent, that even after death, they remain in the lamia's eyes, waiting for an artificer to coax them out again.

table.name: Lich
rows: A lich's body is as much a part of it as a strand of hair on a normal human. It holds no significant connection to it, and discards it with little fanfare. This is because the lich's true power is located within its phylactery, its body acting as little more than a physical conduit for its actions. When a lich is defeated however, not all of its wicked spirit dissipates immediately. Quick action and powerful magic can bind the errant wisps of a lich's essence, allowing one to craft a trinket to track the lich wherever they may reform.

table.name: Lizardfolk
rows: Like an alligator, lizardfolk continuously grow and lose teeth over time. They are not above turning these useful pieces of ivory into tools and weaponry, and indeed, there is no reason why the rest of us shouldn't either.

Lizardfolk hide is already about as strong as leather and can withstand cuts and blows that most humanoids would find lethal. These hides can be tanned just like any other reptiles, with the added advantage that it is already in the right configuration for a humanoid to wear.

table.name: Lizardfolk Shaman
rows: Like an alligator, lizardfolk continuously grow and lose teeth over time. They are not above turning these useful pieces of ivory into tools and weaponry, and indeed, there is no reason why the rest of us shouldn't either.

Lizardfolk hide is already about as strong as leather and can withstand cuts and blows that most humanoids would find lethal. These hides can be tanned just like any other reptiles, with the added advantage that it is already in the right configuration for a humanoid to wear.

entries: The shamans of a lizardfolk tribe are easy to spot. They sport a distinctive spiked ridge starting from the crown of their skull down to the base of their tail. This ridge is considered to be a gift from their god, and is the source of their shamanic powers.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action, you may invoke the powers within this ridge to cast the {@spell polymorph} spell on yourself. The animal form you choose when casting {@spell polymorph} in this way must be a {@creature crocodile|MM}. Once used, this item loses its magical properties and becomes effectively useless.

table.name: Lizardfolk King/Queen
rows: Like an alligator, lizardfolk continuously grow and lose teeth over time. They are not above turning these useful pieces of ivory into tools and weaponry, and indeed, there is no reason why the rest of us shouldn't either.

Lizardfolk hide is already about as strong as leather and can withstand cuts and blows that most humanoids would find lethal. These hides can be tanned just like any other reptiles, with the added advantage that it is already in the right configuration for a humanoid to wear.

entries: The heart of a lizardfolk touched by Sess'Inek is as fetid and rotten as the swamp its owner lives in. This black organ pumps a stinking ichor through a lizardfolk's body, making them stronger and more vicious than its brethren. Eating it can bestow a temporary boon to a normal humanoid, but it is advised only to those with a strong will.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action, you may eat this item. Upon doing so, you gain the following abilities for the next hour: you are able to hold your breath for 15 minutes, you are immune to the {@condition frightened} condition, your AC raises to 15 if it was lower than that as your skin becomes scaly, and once per turn, you may deal an extra {@damage 3d6} damage on a successful melee weapon attack, and gain temporary hit points equal to the extra damage dealt. Upon eating this item, you must also succeed on a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or become berserk. While berserk, you must attempt to make a melee weapon attack against the closest creature to you, and/or move as close to them as possible. You remain berserk until the rest of the effects of eating this item also end.

table.name: Lizardfolk Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} Tage im Wert von {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}
{@dice 1d8} pieces of bone and shell jewelry
1 pouch of swamp mud (good for skin)

table.name: Lycanthropes

entries: Their cursed blood is the one constant that all lycanthropes share regardless of were-shape or original species. Both feared and revered in equal measure, the blood of a lycanthrope is not to be treated carelessly. In the hands of a skilled alchemist, it can be used to dampen the worst side effects of lycanthropy, or spread its contagion even further.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action, you may drink the vial of lycanthrope blood and infect yourself with lycanthropy. The effect is the same as if you were bitten by a lycanthrope of the same type as that you took the blood from. For more information, refer to {@variantrule Player Characters as Lycanthropes|MM} {@homebrew |page 207 of the Monster Manual.}

rows: {@item Moon Muzzle Mixture|HHHVI} or {@item Lycan Gas|HHHVI}

table.name: Magmin
rows: The leftover shell of a magmin, composed of hard magma. It is quite hard and has impressive insulation qualities that allowed it to house a destructive fire elemental. These shells make for useful tools in alchemy, and it is not uncommon for wizards to summon these creatures just to harvest their shells.

Wenn sich die beschworene Form eines Feuerelementars auflöst, hinterlässt sie kleine Glut, die weiterhin Spuren von elementarer Energie enthält. Diese müssen schnell in speziellen Behältern gesammelt werden, um einen weiteren Verfall zu verhindern. Wenn sie richtig gesammelt werden, können sie zur Herstellung eines Elementar-Edelsteins verwendet werden. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

table.name: Manticore
rows: While a manticore's mouth may resemble a human's, its teeth do not. Displayed in rows of jagged viciousness, these teeth are prized as trophies for their intimidating nature.
Of all the natural weapons that a manticore possesses, its tail is probably its most feared. Many mountain expeditions have ended with its members impaled by dozens of razor sharp spikes.

The powerful wings of a manticore create a distinctive silhouette in the sky that many mountaineers dread. The inherent flight magic held in the leather of these wings can be used to craft a useful cloak.

table.name: Medusa
rows: The living snakes of a medusa die once their host does. Harvesting them intact, however, can make for very dangerous whip tails that deliver deadly poisons with each lash.

The heart of a medusa is a sad one. Cursed by their own vanity, a sense of loneliness and regret seems to seep from these hearts. When used in a dark ritual, these hearts can serve as the core reagent for cursing an item with the same uncontrollable vanity of its original host.

entries: The notorious visage of a medusa transforms any creature that gazes upon it to stone. This property persists even into its death, and unfortunate adventurers can find themselves accidentally petrified when they go to inspect their kill. Even though the idea may be macabre, the preserved head of a medusa can be attached to equipment to petrify any that gaze upon it.

entries.name: Use:
entries: The head of the medusa carries the same petrifying gaze ability as listed in the statblock of the {@creature medusa|MM}, with the exception that the head cannot petrify itself.

table.name: Mephit
rows: When a mephit dies, it explodes into a cloud of its base material. If quickly harvested and kept, samples of these base materials can be preserved and used in alchemical mixtures. It is not uncommon for an alchemist's assistant to spend their day summoning and harvesting mephits just to restock their master's supplies. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

table.name: Merfolk
rows: Merfolk come in just about any shade and colour imaginable, a fact that has not been lost on unscrupulous merchants. If you have the stomach for it (or have just found a merfolk that deserved it), a merfolk can be stripped of their scales for resale to surface dwelling tailors and dyers.

table.name: Merfolk Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} Tage im Wert von {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}
1 jar of slightly intoxicating sea snail slime

table.name: Merrow
rows: The scales of a merrow are not as vibrant as those of their merfolk ancestors. They do however still hold some use when ground down for the creation of dyes, and dye factories on the surface will pay a decent sum to get their hands on them.

Compared to regular merfolk, the transformed nature of the merrow makes their blood more useful when used in alchemy. One of the most common uses of their blood is for the ubiquitous potion of water breathing. Ironically, a failed merrow assault can lead to survivors using their blood as a means to go back and hunt their attackers in their own domain.

The claws of a merrow are capable of cleaving through flesh and bone and are a merrow's preferred method of attack. When preserved and reinforced, they can serve as vicious spikes on a deadly trident.

The merrow are twisted merfolk, created from the insane corruption of the Demogorgon. This seed of corruption can be found in their hearts which can be crafted into dark amulets that can grant a portion of the Demon Prince's power, but at great risk to the wearer.

table.name: Mimic
rows: When a mimic is on the hunt, it produces an extremely powerful adhesive that can hold down even the strongest of adventurers. This adhesive remains usable after the mimic's death so long as it is kept in an airtight environment, and is a common industrial material. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

The ooze that secretes from an injured mimic carries many unique properties and is the main contributor to the mimic's extraordinary ability to change its appearance. Alchemists have long since discovered how to mix this substance with other ingredients to create a magical oil that can change the appearance of small items.

table.name: Mind Flayer
rows: The mucus secreted by a well fed mind flayer has a slightly sticky texture and smells roughly of weak formaldehyde. Filled with the thoughts and emotions of the mind flayer's meals, this mucus can undergo an alchemical process to turn into an intoxicating draught known as: Whisper. When consumed, the drinker experiences a rush of euphoria as dozens of minds recount lost knowledge and memories in a cascade of mental whispers. While unpleasant, this drink is considered a high honour in many Underdark societies.

The mouth tentacle of the mind flayer is renowned for affecting more than the physical on every lash. It retains this property beyond the death of its owner, and Underdark interrogators are rumoured to use whips made of these tentacles in their work.
A mind flayer heart is a dark organ, filled with vile humours and thin ichors. When transformed into an amulet, it can grant many of the psionic abilities of an illithid, but at a terrible price.

entries: The incredibly powerful brain of the mind flayer seems to still throb with activity even after removal from its skull. Due to the unique physiology of the illithid race, the consciousness of the mind flayer is still present in the brain, allowing it to be exploited by both adventurers and by the mind flayer's elder brain master alike.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Despite being dead, the intact brain of a mind flayer is treated as if it were still a living mind for the purposes of spells and abilities that can interact directly with minds such as the {@spell detect thoughts} spell. Any time a creature interacts with the mind flayer brain in this way, there is a {@chance 90|10 percent chance|Elder Brain Awareness|The elder brain does not detect the interaction!|The elder brain detects the interaction!} that the elder brain that the mind flayer had a psychic link with becomes aware of this interaction and what occurred during this interaction.

table.name: Minotaur
rows: A minotaur resembles cattle in every way that counts. Taking their hides and tanning them into leather is no more distasteful than doing so to an ordinary bull.

The heart of a minotaur is far larger and stronger than a human's or a bull's. Warped by the dark influence of {@creature Baphomet|MPMM}, this heart carries strong magic that can be brought out by a talented artificer.

The wicked horns of the minotaur have ended more than one hapless adventurer's life. When mounted on a sturdy helm, and with slight magical reinforcement, a wearer can emulate the deadly charge of the horns' original owner.

table.name: Mummy
rows: The bandages of a mummy are marked with necromantic sigils and soaked in foul oils that curse a corpse with eternal undeath. While the magic can only be used on one corpse, the magical reagents can be recycled by resourceful alchemists. As such, these bandages can fetch a decent price.

The body of a cursed mummy remains cursed even after it has been rendered inanimate. Taking the dry dust from this corpse can serve as the basis for a ghastly potion once mixed with other oils and desert roots. Such a potion and fate should only be reserved for those who have committed the worst of crimes (such as making a mummy in the first place).

table.name: Mummy Lord
rows: The bandages of a mummy are marked with necromantic sigils and soaked in foul oils that curse a corpse with eternal undeath. While the magic can only be used on one corpse, the magical reagents can be recycled by resourceful alchemists. As such, these bandages can fetch a decent price.

The body of a cursed mummy remains cursed even after it has been rendered inanimate. Taking the dry dust from this corpse can serve as the basis for a ghastly potion once mixed with other oils and desert roots. Such a potion and fate should only be reserved for those who have committed the worst of crimes (such as making a mummy in the first place).

The heart of a mummy lord is not actually found in a mummy lord's chest but is sequestered away in a separate container somewhere in the mummy lord's lair. It takes great skill to remove and store the shrivelled organ without damaging it, but if done correctly, can provide a powerful base for artificing. It is, however, advised that one finishes their business with the heart quickly, before its owner comes looking for it.

table.name: Myconid Sprout
rows: This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had uses of its rapport spores ability. These spores have a unique ability to transmit thought between the myconid and other intelligent beings. With some reverse engineering, alchemists have managed to use these spores to create a potion that simulates a similar effect in other creatures.

table.name: Myconid Adult
rows: This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had uses of its rapport spores ability. These spores have a unique ability to transmit thought between the myconid and other intelligent beings. With some reverse engineering, alchemists have managed to use these spores to create a potion that simulates a similar effect in other creatures.

entries: This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had use of its pacifying spores ability. The pacifying spores of an adult myconid are capable of stopping even the largest of creatures, if at least temporarily. Stored properly, they can be packed into small clusters and used in much the same manner as their original owner used them.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may make a ranged weapon attack and throw the pouch of pacifying spores at a target within 10 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

table.name: Myconid Sovereign
rows: This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had uses of its rapport spores ability. These spores have a unique ability to transmit thought between the myconid and other intelligent beings. With some reverse engineering, alchemists have managed to use these spores to create a potion that simulates a similar effect in other creatures.

entries: This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had use of its pacifying spores ability. The pacifying spores of an adult myconid are capable of stopping even the largest of creatures, if at least temporarily. Stored properly, they can be packed into small clusters and used in much the same manner as their original owner used them.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may make a ranged weapon attack and throw the pouch of pacifying spores at a target within 10 feet. The target must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

The hallucination spores created by the myconid sovereign create a strong psychedelic effect in any creature that inhales them. Imbibers have described visions of strong lights and strange images, and an overall satisfied feeling afterwards. Underdark societies are known to hunt sovereigns down just for these spores, which is a shame because most would happily share the spores to any visitor who just asked politely.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may make a ranged weapon attack at a creature within 10 feet by throwing the pouch at them. Upon a successful hit, the target must succeed on a {@dc 12} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. The {@condition poisoned} target is {@condition incapacitated} while it hallucinates. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

This item can only be harvested if the myconid being harvested still had use of its animating spores ability. The animating spores of a myconid sovereign holds a strange place between schools of magic. Holding characteristics of necromantic, enchantment, and transfiguration, these spores continue to vex even the foremost scholars of the day.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action, you may sprinkle these spores over the corpse of a humanoid or a Large or smaller beast within 5 feet. In 24 hours, the corpse rises as a {@filter spore servant|bestiary|search=spore servant} {@homebrew |(refer to the Monster Manual for the statblock)}. The corpse stays animated for {@dice 1d4+1} weeks or until destroyed, and it can't be animated again in this way.

table.name: Bone Naga
rows: Virtually identical to the bones of an ordinary serpent, except on a larger scale. When ground up into a powder and then brewed into a tea however, it creates an intoxicating drink that some cultures have used for spiritual purposes. Those that have drunk it have claimed visions of long-forgotten histories, but they are inevitably forgotten once the drink has left their system.

Nagas require no glands to produce their venom as their fangs remain venomous even when the naga is reduced to a skeletal form. Proper extraction and then re-smithing allows these fangs to serve as powerful weapons with an extra poisonous punch. Beware though, as a revived naga may not take kindly to the idea of a mortal running around with one of their teeth.

table.name: Spirit Naga
rows: Virtually identical to the bones of an ordinary serpent, except on a larger scale. When ground up into a powder and then brewed into a tea however, it creates an intoxicating drink that some cultures have used for spiritual purposes. Those that have drunk it have claimed visions of long-forgotten histories, but they are inevitably forgotten once the drink has left their system.

Nagas are renowned for their rejuvenation abilities, and this property transfers to their scales. Indeed, powdered naga scales are one of many potential catalysts required when brewing the ubiquitous healing potion.

Nagas require no glands to produce their venom as their fangs remain venomous even when the naga is reduced to a skeletal form. Proper extraction and then re-smithing allows these fangs to serve as powerful weapons with an extra poisonous punch. Beware though, as a revived naga may not take kindly to the idea of a mortal running around with one of their teeth.

table.name: Guardian Naga
rows: Virtually identical to the bones of an ordinary serpent, except on a larger scale. When ground up into a powder and then brewed into a tea however, it creates an intoxicating drink that some cultures have used for spiritual purposes. Those that have drunk it have claimed visions of long-forgotten histories, but they are inevitably forgotten once the drink has left their system.

Nagas are renowned for their rejuvenation abilities, and this property transfers to their scales. Indeed, powdered naga scales are one of many potential catalysts required when brewing the ubiquitous healing potion.

Nagas require no glands to produce their venom as their fangs remain venomous even when the naga is reduced to a skeletal form. Proper extraction and then re-smithing allows these fangs to serve as powerful weapons with an extra poisonous punch. Beware though, as a revived naga may not take kindly to the idea of a mortal running around with one of their teeth.

entries: (0 if willingly given by the guardian naga)

The heart of a guardian naga may be taken by force, but it is only useful when given freely by the benevolent creatures. When eaten, the recipient gains the naga's rejuvenation ability for at least one death. In exchange, the naga's own cycle of rebirth is temporarily halted. A guardian naga only does this when it sees great potential in a mortal creature and wishes to be a part of that creature fulfilling their destiny.

entries.name: Use:
entries: If the naga heart is taken and eaten under the free and willing permission of the guardian naga, the eater temporarily gains the ability to return to life after death. If the eater dies, they will return to life in {@dice 1d6} days and regain all hit points, missing body parts, and be cured of all non-magical diseases. Only a {@spell wish} spell can prevent this trait from functioning. In addition, the naga from whom the heart was taken loses its rejuvenation ability until the creature that ate their heart returns to life for the first time using this ability. After the eater returns to life for the first time using this ability, they lose this ability.

table.name: Nightmare
rows: Nightmares have the ability to grant fire resistance to any creature riding them, ostensibly to avoid burning their riders to death. Upon their death, taking some of their ashes and leaving them in a crucible overnight can create one of the key ingredients of a potion of fire resistance.

The hooves of a nightmare are jet black and with a bit of artificing, along with expert crafting, they can be turned into miniature statues of the very nightmare they were taken from. This statue contains much of the original nightmare's abilities, trapped inside a figurine form.
{@item Figurine of Wondrous Power, Obsidian Steed|DMG}

table.name: Nothic

entries: The nothic brain is immense; existing as both a testament and mockery to the nothic's former intellectual callings. Despite its veil of madness, wells of knowledge still exist within it, for those that know how to bring it out.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend 1 day pulping, drying, and mixing this item with various reagents. The resulting mixture creates a magical ink that contains magical knowledge. A character with at least 3 levels in the wizard class may use this ink to write in their spellbook. If they do so, they subconsciously write down a random spell (chosen by the DM) of 2nd level or lower into their spellbook. Regardless of the level of the spell, this transcription takes 2 hours and costs nothing except the usage of all the ink. This copied spell functions as well as any other spell copied into the book through a mundane method.

rows: The bulging, lidless eye of a nothic is its main source of power. Capable of seeing more than mortals were meant to, it provides a good framework for constructing magical devices capable of performing similar feats as its original owner.

table.name: Ogre
rows: An ogre has a repugnant odor that seems to combine mouldy cheese, sour feet, and dank mud all at once. The fat around their rotund bellies seem to be the most potent source of this smell, and it takes a very stalwart alchemist to render this fat into tallow to make a vaguely magical candle.
The tough skin of an ogre is undoubtedly smelly and unpleasant. However, when tanned, it makes for a very durable leather, and many tanners would be glad to have them.
Brutish, rough, and very large, the hands of an ogre are meant for little more than wielding a club to smash those smaller than their owner.

table.name: Half-Ogre
rows: The blood of a regular ogre is too foreign and extreme to be compatible with that of a humanoid's system. A half-ogre on the other hand has the perfect dilution of humanoid blood for it to not be toxic to a humanoid, while still conferring the power of its giant progenitor.

table.name: Oni
rows: The horns of an oni are incredibly hard and serve only to add to the oni's devilish appearance. They carry only trace amounts of the oni's innate magic, but they make good magical implements. Cannibalistic cults have often taken to using these horns as ceremonial flasks in their depraved rituals.
Despite being ogres, oni blood carries regenerative properties usually only seen in trolls. This powerful blood is one of the many potential catalysts used for brewing the ubiquitous healing potion.

The eyes of an oni appear to glow long after they have been pried from their foul sockets. If you are willing to use them, they can be crafted into goggles useful for the adventurer with no darkvision.
The hands of an oni are much like any other ogre's; tough and powerful. When taken to a blacksmith with a magical bent, they can be crafted into gauntlets of ogre power just like any other ogre's.
The heart of an oni is black as a moonless night and just as terrifying. Used as a conduit, an amulet crafted from this organ can grant the wearer some of the oni's magical properties.

entries: A sample of a black pudding. Inert due to lacking enough biomass to constitute a full ooze, it nevertheless retains its acidic properties. Can be used as a potent acid. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: A vial of black residue can be poured onto nonmagical wood or metal. The black residue eats through 2 inches of these materials per round for the next 10 rounds, after which the ooze becomes too diluted to continue.

The gelatinous residue from a gelatinous cube carries much of the same acidic properties from its original form. Unlike samples taken from other oozes, the gelatinous cube's acid is difficult to identify when mixed with other liquids, making it the substance of choice among assassins with a subtler touch. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: Drinking the gelatinous residue automatically deals {@damage 6d6} acid damage to the drinker. The gelatinous residue may be mixed with up to 5 oz. of other liquid and still retain this property. A {@dc 15} Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check can identify a liquid that has had gelatinous residue mixed into it.

Not as potent as a black pudding, but highly acidic nonetheless. Some blacksmithing techniques actually use this acid in advanced smithing projects, but the difficulty and volatility of controlling the residue has made this a rather esoteric art-form. {@b Requires {@item enchanted vial|HHHVI}.}

entries.name: Use:
entries: A vial of gray residue can be poured on a piece of nonmagical metal. This ooze will eat through 2 inches of that metal every round for the next 10 rounds, after which it becomes too diluted to continue.

table.name: Ochre Residue
rows: The wobbly material of an ochre jelly is not as potent as other oozes. Indeed, it is weak enough that it can be treated with large amounts of other ingredients and consumed safely. It is not actually uncommon to stumble upon a tribe of kobolds that have set themselves up in a dungeon and farm the local ochre jellies in order to brew a rather noxious ale.

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, Luthic, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

table.name: Orc War Chief

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, Luthic, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

The heart of an orc touched by Gruumsh is considerably larger than a regular one. Many would find the consumption of this heart to be barbaric, but it would be no more barbaric than what the original owner of this heart has done.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may consume this heart. For the next 10 minutes, you deal an extra {@damage 1d8} damage when you hit with a weapon attack. This benefit can not be taken by any character with Elvish ancestry.

rows: Orcish war chiefs famously decorate their large tusks with all manner of jewelery and precious stones, presumably so you can be dazzled by their riches before they bite your head off. Many merchants will pay a good price for these tusks, if only for the sheer novelty of it.

table.name: Orc Eye of Gruumsh

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, Luthic, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

The heart of an orc touched by Gruumsh is considerably larger than a regular one. Many would find the consumption of this heart to be barbaric, but it would be no more barbaric than what the original owner of this heart has done.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may consume this heart. For the next 10 minutes, you deal an extra {@damage 1d8} damage when you hit with a weapon attack. This benefit can not be taken by any character with Elvish ancestry.

rows: The remaining eye of an orc who has already sacrificed one to their god still carries magical potential. Arcanists and religious scholars would pay a fair price for one of these eyes, to further study the machinations of the evil orcish god. The fact that this eye seems to always glare at anyone with elvish ancestry should probably just be ignored.

entries: The gift of fertility that was granted to the orcs by their deity, Luthic, also gave their other fluids full compatibility with other humanoids. As such, drinking the blood of an orc can temporarily grant other humanoids some of the legendary ferocity of the orcs.

entries.name: Use:
entries: When you drink this vial of blood, you feel more aggressive for the next 10 minutes. During this time, you may spend your bonus action to move up to your speed toward a hostile creature you can see. After the 10 minutes have passed, you must succeed on a {@dc 10} Constitution saving throw or suffer one point of {@condition exhaustion}.

The heart of an orc touched by Gruumsh is considerably larger than a regular one. Many would find the consumption of this heart to be barbaric, but it would be no more barbaric than what the original owner of this heart has done.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may consume this heart. For the next 10 minutes, you deal an extra {@damage 1d8} damage when you hit with a weapon attack. This benefit can not be taken by any character with Elvish ancestry.

table.name: Orc Trinket Table
rows: {@dice 1d4} Tage im Wert von {@item rations (1 day)|PHB|rations}

table.name: Otyugh
rows: As disgusting as the idea may sound, otyugh bile, capable of digesting just about anything, actually makes for a very good medicine for indigestion. A common remedy prescibred by a village's medicine woman is a dose of diluted otyugh bile mixed with a spoonful of honey (mostly to mask the taste).

entries: An otyugh's saliva is not actually poisonous, but it is loaded with so much bacteria and disease that it may as well be.

entries.name: Use:
entries: This saliva can be used to coat up to 5 pieces of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes 1 minute. For the next minute, any creature successfully hit must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw against disease or become {@condition poisoned} until the disease is cured. For every 24 hours that elapse, the target must repeat the saving throw, reducing its hit point maximum by {@dice 1d10} on a failure. The disease is cured on a success. The target dies if the disease reduces its hit point maximum to 0. This reduction to the target's hit point maximum lasts until the disease is cured.

rows: The tentacles of an otyugh are tipped with incredibly sharp needles that both pierce its foes and allow it to drag them around. Underdark slavers are often found with whips made from these tentacles, designed to capture their prey alive.

An odd cluster of nerves at the section in which the otyugh's tentacles meet its back. The composition is incompatible with the more complicated brain structure of a humanoid, but it actually does work on simpler life forms like beasts.

table.name: Owlbear
rows: The feathers of an owlbear are noticeably soft and downy, in contrast to their more ferocious appearance. While these feathers make for poor fletching, they actually do make fantastic bedding material, and owlbear feather stuffed pillows are the hallmark of any well equipped bedroom.

The liver of an owlbear is a potent medicinal ingredient, used to treat everything from indigestion, to kidney stones, to mudgut. Unfortunately, this very property has led to owlbears facing overhunting in some regions.

Ask anybody who has once tried to hide from an owlbear, and they will tell you of how futile that effort is. Their keen eyesight, hearing, and sense of smell, combined with their eerie owl-like tendency to twist their heads behind them while tracking, make them a terrifying predator to elude. A scarf made from a part of their carcass also grants some level of these senses, giving its owner some level of heightened awareness.

table.name: Pegasus
rows: Pure white, majestic, and incredibly durable, the hair of a pegasus is coveted as a crafting material. Everything from rope, to instruments, to bows have been strung with pegasus hair, and always sold at a premium.

The hooves of a pegasus can be ground down and rendered into a glue like a regular horse's. This glue however has a certain glittery imperfection in it that is actually enjoyed by noble ladies fond of extravagance. This glue has been converted into various cosmetics or as a final flourish to an already decadent gown.
Pegasus blood is a brilliant sheen of silver with a rainbow reflection on its surface. Well known as a medicine, it is often sold to middle-aged men as a fertility potion.

The glorious wings of a pegasus, resembling two nimbuses on a corporeal body. It takes a very steady hand to remove these fragile appendages without ruining them, but if done correctly, they can be used as ingredients in the ever useful potion of flying.

table.name: Peryton
rows: The large horns of a peryton are considered quite striking for their strange black lustre. Whether used as a decoration or ground up for medicine, they tend to fetch a decent price. There is also a rumour that a set of dice crafted from the horns of a peryton are particularly easy to use in cheating. This is unsubstantiated, however.
Perytons have a strange fixation with hearts. While theories abound of their origin in regards to the eating of hearts, it can be confirmed that a peryton's own heart does carry dark magical energy.
The black wings of a peryton are incredibly powerful and agile. When removed properly, they can be used as ingredients in the ever useful potion of flying.

table.name: Piercer
rows: The horrible smelling musk of a piercer, while unpleasant, is not debilitatingly so. Ironically enough, this musk can undergo an alchemical process to be transformed into a rather expensive perfume. Of course, those marketing it are usually reluctant to tell their buyers what it is made out of.

The slug-like piercer is covered in a rock-like shell that gives it the appearance of a stalactite or stalagmite. This hard shell has been repurposed into many things in Underdark societies including bowls, furniture, and various tools.

entries: The ubiquitous dust dropped by the wings of pixies. Incredibly magical, yet volatile, it is virtually impossible for a non-pixie to determine what will happen when sprinkled on a creature.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action, you may sprinkle some pixie dust on a creature next to you. If sprinkled on an unwilling creature, they may resist any resulting effect by succeeding on a {@dc 12} Wisdom saving throw. If sprinkled on a willing creature, or an unwilling creature that failed their saving throw, roll {@dice 1d10} and consult the pixie dust effect table for the result. A small pouch of pixie dust has enough dust in it for 3 uses.

The venom of a pseudodragon has a soporific effect that some alchemists have actually used to create a draught to treat insomnia. Of course, in its pure state, it can still be used as an effective tranquilliser.

entries.name: Use:
entries: Can be used to coat 1 piece of slashing or piercing ammunition or one slashing or piercing weapon. Applying the poison takes an action. The next time that the coated ammunition or weapon successfully hits a creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. If the saving throw fails by 5 or more, the target falls {@condition unconscious} for the same duration, or until it takes damage or another creature uses an action to shake it awake.

table.name: Purple Worm
rows: It is a simple fact of Underdark life that you need to have a purple worm ward if you wish to have a long-term settlement. Ironically, these wards require the blood of a purple worm in order to be created. In a way, though it is fitting that only a society that can kill a purple worm can be protected from them. Natural selection at its finest, as it were.

entries: The incredibly corrosive bile of a purple worm is coveted by miners for being able to literally eat through rocks that would otherwise take weeks of work to break through. Just be careful when harvesting it, however, you don't want to be known as the fool who was eaten by an already slain purple worm.

entries.name: Use:
entries: As an action you may make a ranged weapon attack to throw a vial of purple worm bile at a target within 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against the target, treating the vial as an improvised object. On a hit, the target suffers {@damage 5d6} acid damage.

rows: Purple worm teeth resemble stalactites and stalagmites in their cavernous mouth more than anything else. Larger than a grown human's arm, these teeth make very good crafting materials and are a rich source of ivory. Alternatively, they can be crafted into fine weapons.
{@filter Any +2 melee piercing weapon|items|source=|type=melee weapon|category=|weapon damage type=p|bonus=weapon attack and damage rolls|search=+2}

Despite what you may think, it is not much safer to be on the opposite side of a purple worm's mouth, as its tail is perhaps even more deadly. When the stinger head is taken and re-crafted into a weapon, it can deliver payloads of venom just as it did when attached to its original owner.

With all the dirt and rock that a purple worm chews through, it inevitably swallows some precious gems and metals. These are not digested easily and often clump together in the purple worm's stomach. Melded together by digestive acids and pressure, they form beautiful unique pearls that fetch incredibly high prices on open markets.

table.name: Quaggoth
rows: Shaggy and coarse, it would not be immediately apparent that quaggoth fur has much use as anything except as a trophy. The fur however has remarkable insulation qualities, and while uncomfortable, can stuff a coat to keep an adventurer warm in even the deepest and darkest Underdark tunnel.

Due to their horrible Underdark diets, quaggoths have developed several enzymes and antibodies that make them immune to poisons. If used in an alchemy recipe, it creates a potion of poison resistance.

entries: The psionic energy of the Underdark occasionally causes mutations in the susceptible quaggoth population, creating what is known as a thonot. Their brains are noticeably larger and capable of psionic feats themselves. When eaten, these psionic abilities are temporarily bequeathed to the eater.

entries.name: Use:
entries: You may spend an action to eat this brain. For the next hour, you may cast the {@spell feather fall} and {@spell mage hand} spells at will without using a spell slot or requiring any spell components.

table.name: Rakshasa
rows: The hatred and malice inherent in a rakshasa is embodied in their deformed claws, capable of imparting a curse that spites any it strikes. When burned in an occult ritual, the ashes can create a dye used in dark rituals to curse unwary hoarders of magical items.

The rakshasa's tendency to kill and subsume the lives of its victims is almost legendary. The heart of the rakshasa drips with this malicious coveting of others' identities, and can be refashioned into an amulet that allows its wielder to do the same.

While not as potent once removed from its original body, the removed hide of a rakshasa still carries the magical resistance that it is famous for. When reinforced properly, it becomes a fearsome cloak that shrugs off weak spells.

table.name: Young Remorhaz
rows: Anybody who has slain a remorhaz can attest to the virtually boiling blood that spews forth from its open wounds. This blood remains supernaturally warm long after being removed from its body, and arctic cultures use bladders of this as a form of insulation and heating.

The remorhaz has the uncanny ability to sense the movements of creatures around it, based mostly around its incredibly senstive antennae. If taken in whole, they may be re-adapted to be used as a pair of dowsing rods for security purposes.
The thick, iron-like scales of even a young remorhaz have incredible insulation properties and can regulate the creature's insect-like body.

table.name: Remorhaz
